question: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a cough and mild shortness of breath for the past 12 hours. He has not had fever. He has been to the emergency department 4 times during the past 6 months for treatment of asthma exacerbations. His 9-month-old sister was treated for bronchiolitis a week ago. His father has allergic rhinitis. Current medications include an albuterol inhaler and a formoterol-fluticasone inhaler. He appears in mild distress. His temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 28/min, and blood pressure is 86/60 mm Hg. Examination shows mild intercostal and subcostal retractions. Pulmonary examination shows decreased breath sounds and mild expiratory wheezing throughout the right lung field. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.F: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

question: A 17-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for evaluation of mild acne. Six months ago, the girl developed papules over her back and shoulders. Her mother reports that her daughter has only been wearing clothes that cover her complete back and shoulders recently and that she spends a lot of time checking her skin in the mirror. After reading an article that suggested sugar was a possible cause of acne, she tried a low-carb diet, which resulted in a weight loss 5.2-kg (11.5-lb) but no change in her skin condition. The patient describes herself as “ugly.” Over the past 6 months, she quit the swim team, stopped swim training, and stayed home from school on several occasions. She appears sad and distressed. She is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 62 kg (136.7 lb); BMI is 21.4 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a few small papules but numerous, widespread scratch marks over the neck, back, and buttocks. On mental status examination, she is depressed and irritable. There is no evidence of suicidal ideation. After establishing a therapeutic alliance, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.A: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.
choices.E: Reassure the patient that the skin findings are not severe

question: A 9-hour-old newborn female is found in the newborn nursery with a diffuse swelling of the scalp not present at birth. The child was born at 38 weeks of gestation to a 28-year-old gravida 3. The mother went into spontaneous labor, but the delivery was complicated by a prolonged second stage of labor. The child’s Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. The pregnancy was complicated by preeclampsia in the mother which was well-controlled throughout the pregnancy. On physical exam, the child appears to be in mild distress and has a 4x5 cm ecchymotic area of swelling over the bilateral parietal bones. Serial assessments of the child’s head circumference over the next 12 hours show no change in the size of the swelling. This patient’s condition affects which of the following spaces or potential spaces?

choices.F: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

A vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery was eventually performed. The child’s Apgar scores were 8 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. On physical exam, the child appears to be in mild distress and has a 4x5 cm ecchymotic area of swelling over the bilateral parietal bones. - Question asks which space or potential space is affected by the condition
meta.gold_context: "vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery"
meta.reason: The vacuum-assisted vaginal delivery is the critical piece of information that points toward the diagnosis of a subgaleal hemorrhage, which occurs in the space between the scalp and galea aponeurosis. Without this context, it is difficult to distinguish this condition from other types of scalp swelling such as cephalohematoma or caput succedaneum, which involve different spaces. The answer depends heavily on recognizing the association between vacuum delivery and subgaleal hemorrhage.

question: A 43-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a work-related accident in which both arms were amputated. The trauma surgery resident initiates the massive transfusion protocol and orders whole blood, O negative, which she explains is the universal donor. Her vital signs are as follows: blood pressure 125/70 mm Hg, heart rate 82/min, respiratory rate 15/min, and temperature 38.7°C (101.7°F). On examination, her GCS score is 15. Pulmonary, cardiac, and abdominal examinations are within normal limits. A neurologic examination does not reveal focal symptoms. Moderate neck stiffness and a positive Brudzinski’s sign are noted. Which of the following would you expect to note in a CSF sample?

choices.B: Formation of a spiderweb clot in the collected CSF
choices.C: Haemophilus influenzae growth is the CSF culture
choices.E: Listeria monocytogenes growth in the CSF culture

question: A 1-year-old boy is brought to his pediatrician for a follow-up appointment. He was recently diagnosed with failure to thrive and developmental delay. He has a coarse face with small deep orbits, proptotic eyes, big lips, and gingival hyperplasia. His skin is pale with decreased elasticity. His lung and heart sounds are normal. choices.C: The lysosomal enzymes are secreted from the cells instead of being targeted to lysosomes because of lack of mannose phosphorylation on N-linked glycoproteins.
choices.D: Due to enzyme deficiency, glycogen is extensively accumulated within the hepatocytes.
choices.E: The symptoms result from defective glycolysis, which results in a total energy deficiency.

question: An 8-year-old male presents to his pediatrician for a follow-up appointment for persistent fatigue. His mother reports that the patient’s teacher called her yesterday to tell her that her son has been sitting out of recess every day for the past week. The patient first developed symptoms of fatigue and weakness several years ago and has returned to the physician with similar episodes once or twice a year. These episodes seem to sometimes be triggered by viral illnesses, but others have no identifiable trigger. The patient has been on daily folate supplementation with some improvement and requires red blood cell transfusions several times a year. He has an allergy to sulfa drugs, and last month he was treated with amoxicillin for an ear infection. His paternal grandfather was recently diagnosed with multiple myeloma, but his parents deny any other family history of hematologic conditions. Her temperature is 99.0°F (37.2°C), blood pressure is 103/76 mmHg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 14/min. On physical exam, the patient is tired-appearing with conjunctival pallor. Laboratory tests performed during this visit reveal the following: Leukocyte count: 9,7000/mm^3 Hemoglobin: 8.4 g/dL Hematocrit: 27% Mean corpuscular volume: 97 µm^3 Platelet count: 338,000/mm^3 Reticulocyte index (RI): 4.2% What is the next step in management?

choices.E: Vaccinations followed by splenectomy and penicillin for one year

He appears to have abnormally long extremities as well as an upward lens dislocation on ophthalmologic exam. A mutation leading to a defect in which of the following proteins is the most likely cause of his condition?

meta.key_information:
- 8-year old boy with newly found scoliosis  
- 99th percentile for height and 70th percentile for weight  
- Abnormally long extremities  
- Upward lens dislocation on ophthalmologic exam  
- Mutation in a protein causing the condition
meta.gold_context: Upward lens dislocation on ophthalmologic exam
meta.reason: The upward lens dislocation is a distinctive clinical sign that helps differentiate the underlying genetic disorder. It is a hallmark feature of Marfan syndrome, which is caused by mutations in fibrillin (option E). Without this key detail, the question becomes much more challenging because scoliosis and tall stature with long extremities can be seen in multiple conditions, and the candidate would have less specific information to pinpoint fibrillin as the defective protein.

question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are concerned about his “strange behavior”. His teachers say he daydreams a lot and he is very good at art, being able to recreate his favorite cartoon characters in great detail. On physical assessment, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician but talks incessantly. The child’s grammar and vocabulary seem normal but his speech is slightly labored, and he can’t seem to tell that the physician is not really interested in hearing about his interests. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

original_question: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents because they are concerned about his “strange behavior”. The child throws tantrums for no reason and does not respond to punishment or reward. He also has a “strange obsession” with collecting rocks that he finds on his way to and from school to the point where his room is filled with rocks. He plays alone in his room, lining the rocks up, organizing them by size, shape, or color, and he will randomly bark or make high-pitched noises without provocation. His teachers say he daydreams a lot and is very good at art, being able to recreate his favorite cartoon characters in great detail. On physical assessment, the patient does not make eye contact with the physician but talks incessantly about his rock collection. The child’s grammar and vocabulary seem normal but his speech is slightly labored, and he can’t seem to tell that the physician is not really interested in hearing about his rock collection. meta.key_information:

- Behavioral problems: unprovoked tantrums, no response to punishment or reward  
- Obsession with collecting and organizing rocks  
- Repetitive behaviors: lining up rocks, making random noises (barking, high-pitched sounds)

meta.gold_context: Obsession with collecting and organizing rocks, repetitive behaviors (lining up rocks, making random noises), and poor eye contact/social interaction
meta.reason: The gold context highlights the core features of autism spectrum disorder (ASD): restricted, repetitive behaviors (rock collecting and organizing, repetitive noises), and social communication deficits (poor eye contact, lack of social reciprocity). These symptoms distinguish ASD from other disorders listed in the options. Without this information, it would be difficult to differentiate ASD from other behavioral or neurodevelopmental disorders such as ADHD or Tourette’s syndrome. The obsession with rocks and repetitive behaviors are key diagnostic clues that lead to the correct diagnosis.

meta.reason: This description of the protein’s dual forms and functions is the critical clue that identifies the protein as fibronectin. Without this information, it would be difficult to distinguish fibronectin from other extracellular matrix proteins or collagens, making the question much harder to answer correctly.

question: A 70-year-old man presents for his annual check-up. He says he feels well except for occasional abdominal pain. She has a flat face with upward-slanting eyes and a short neck. The tongue seems to be protruding from a small mouth. She has poor muscle tone and excessive joint laxity. The pediatrician orders an analysis of the infant’s chromosomes, also known as a karyotype (see image). The infant is most likely to suffer from which of the following conditions in the future?

meta.key_information:
- 35-year-old woman and 37-year-old husband trying to conceive for 4 years  
- Baby girl born at 38 weeks with abnormalities: flat face, upward-slanting eyes, short neck, protruding tongue, poor muscle tone, excessive joint laxity  
- Pediatrician orders chromosomal analysis (karyotype)  
- Infant’s future risk of specific conditions (options include leukemias, immotile cilia syndrome, macroorchidism, sickling)  
- Answer: Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL)
meta.gold_context: The description of the infant’s physical abnormalities: "flat face with upward-slanting eyes and a short neck. The tongue seems to be protruding from a small mouth. She has poor muscle tone and excessive joint laxity."
meta.reason: These physical features are classic signs of Down syndrome (trisomy 21), which is strongly associated with an increased risk of acute lymphoblastic leukemia. Without these characteristic phenotypic clues, it would be very difficult to link the chromosomal abnormality to the correct future condition. The karyotype image is referenced but not provided here, so the physical description is the critical clue that guides the diagnosis and the associated risk.

question: A 52-year-old man comes to the physician because of right knee pain and swelling for 2 days. Four days ago, he tripped at home and landed on his knees. He reports an episode of diarrhea 3 weeks ago that resolved after 4 days without treatment. He drinks 1–2 ounces of whiskey daily and occasionally more on weekends. His brother has ankylosing spondylitis. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination of the right leg shows an abrasion below the patella. There is swelling and tenderness of the right knee; range of motion is limited by pain. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for this patient's condition?

question: A 39-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with new onset lower extremity edema, fatigue, and hematuria. question: A 34-year-old Ethiopian woman who recently moved to the United States presents for evaluation to a surgical outpatient clinic with painful ulceration in her right breast for the last 2 months. She is worried because the ulcer is increasing in size. On further questioning, she says that she also has a discharge from her right nipple. She had her 2nd child 4 months ago and was breastfeeding the baby until the pain started getting worse in the past few weeks, and is now unbearable. According to her health records from Africa, her physician prescribed antimicrobials multiple times with a diagnosis of mastitis, but she did not improve significantly. Her mother and aunt died of breast cancer at 60 and 58 years of age, respectively. On examination, the right breast is enlarged and firm, with thickened skin, diffuse erythema, edema, and an ulcer measuring 3 × 3 cm. White-Gray nipple discharge is present. The breast is tender with axillary and cervical adenopathy. Mammography is ordered, which shows a mass with a large area of calcifications, parenchymal distortion, and extensive soft tissue and trabecular thickening in the affected breast. The patient subsequently undergoes core-needle and full-thickness skin punch biopsies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

question: A 48-year-old woman presented to the hospital with a headache, intermittent fevers and chills, generalized arthralgias, excessive thirst, increased fluid intake, and a progressive rash that developed on her back. Three days before seeking evaluation at the hospital, she noticed a small, slightly raised lesion appearing like a spider or insect bite on her back, which she considered to be a scab covering the affected region. The patient's fever reached 39.4°C (102.9°F) 2 days before coming to the hospital, with an intensifying burning sensation on the affected site. When a family member examined the bite, it was noticed that the bump had transformed into a circular rash. The patient took over-the-counter ibuprofen for intense pain so she could sleep through the night. The day before her hospital visit, the patient felt exhausted but managed to complete a normal workday. On the day of the hospital visit, she awoke feeling very ill, with shooting joint pains, high fevers, and excessive thirst, which led to her to seek medical attention. On physical examination, her temperature was 40.1°C (104.2°F), and there was a large circular red rash with a bulls-eye appearance (17 × 19 cm in diameter) on her back. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. Her past medical and surgical histories were not significant. She recalled a walk in the woods 3 weeks before this exam but denied finding a tick or any other ectoparasite on her body. She denied any nutritional or inhalational allergies. Based on her symptoms, medical history, and physical examination findings, the attending physician decides to institute antimicrobial therapy immediately. Which antimicrobial drug did the physician prescribe?

choices.A: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

question: A 74-year-old woman with a past medical history of hypertension, peripheral artery disease, and migraine headaches presents to the emergency department with a two hour history of severe abdominal pain. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 18.5 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a symmetrical rash over his shoulders and knees. A photograph of the rash on his left shoulder is shown. Rubbing the affected skin does not lead to upper epidermal layer separation from the lower layer. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 63.2 μm3, and platelet count is 450,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this skin condition?

choices.B: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

He has no history of serious illness except for recurrent episodes of diarrhea and abdominal cramps, which have occurred every once in a while over the past three months. He describes his stools as greasy and foul-smelling. He does not smoke or drink alcohol. He does not take illicit drugs. He takes no medications. He is 180 cm (5 ft 11 in) tall and weighs 60 kg (132 lb); BMI is 18.5 kg/m2. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a symmetrical rash over his shoulders and knees. A photograph of the rash on his left shoulder is shown. Rubbing the affected skin does not lead to upper epidermal layer separation from the lower layer. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.2 g/dL, mean corpuscular volume is 63.2 μm3, and platelet count is 450,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy for this skin condition?

meta.key_information:
- 22-year-old man with a skin rash over shoulders and elbows for 5 days  
- Severe itching and burning sensation  
- History of recurrent diarrhea and abdominal cramps over 3 months  
- Stools described as greasy and foul-smelling  
- Physical exam: symmetrical rash over shoulders and knees, no epidermal separation on rubbing  
- Lab findings: anemia with low MCV (microcytic anemia), elevated platelets
meta.gold_context: History of recurrent diarrhea and abdominal cramps with greasy, foul-smelling stools
meta.reason: The history of recurrent diarrhea and greasy, foul-smelling stools is critical because it suggests malabsorption, which is strongly associated with the diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis secondary to celiac disease. This clinical context guides the choice of pharmacotherapy (oral dapsone). Without this information, the rash could be mistaken for other dermatologic conditions, making it difficult to select the correct treatment.

question: A 29-year-old G1P1 woman presents to her primary care physician with unilateral breast pain. She has been healthy without any problems until 3 days ago, when she developed left breast pain, purulent nipple discharge, and malaise. Her past medical history is notable for obesity and generalized anxiety disorder. She takes sertraline. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Her temperature is 100.8°F (38.2°C), blood pressure is 128/78 mmHg, pulse is 91/min, and respirations are 17/min. On exam, she appears lethargic but is able to answer questions appropriately. Her right breast appears normal. Her left breast is tender to palpation, warm to the touch, and swollen relative to the right breast. There is a visible fissure in the left nipple that expresses minimal purulent discharge. Which of the following pathogens is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?

choices.F: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

question: A 33-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 26 weeks' gestation comes to the emergency department because of frequent contractions. The contractions are 40 seconds each, occurring every 2 minutes, and increasing in intensity. Her temperature is 36.9°C (98.4°F), heart rate is 88/min, and blood pressure is 126/76 mm Hg. Contractions are felt on the abdomen. There is clear fluid in the vulva and the introitus. The cervix is dilated to 5 cm, 70% effaced, and station of the head is -2. A fetal ultrasound shows no abnormalities in the spine and a four chamber heart. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

question: A 19-year-old woman presents with worsening pain in her neck for the past 5 days. She says she is not able to wear her tie for her evening job because it is too painful. She also reports associated anxiety, palpitations, and lethargy for the past 10 days. Past medical history is significant for a recent 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms about 20 days ago which resolved spontaneously. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks beer with friends on weekends. Her vital signs include: blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg, pulse 118/min. On physical examination, her distal extremities are warm and sweaty. There is mild symmetrical swelling of the thyroid gland. No nodules palpated. An ECG is normal. Laboratory findings are significant for low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), elevated T4 and T3 levels, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 30 mm/hr. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s most likely diagnosis?

choices.C: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

original_question: A 19-year-old woman presents with worsening pain in her neck for the past 5 days. She says she is not able to wear her tie for her evening job because is it too painful. She also reports associated anxiety, palpitations, and lethargy for the past 10 days. Past medical history is significant for a recent 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms about 20 days ago which resolved spontaneously. She is a non-smoker and occasionally drinks beer with friends on weekends. Her vital signs include: blood pressure 110/80 mm Hg, pulse 118/min. On physical examination, her distal extremities are warm and sweaty. There is severe bilateral tenderness to palpation of her thyroid gland, as well as mild symmetrical swelling noted. No nodules palpated. An ECG is normal. Laboratory findings are significant for low thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), elevated T4 and T3 levels, and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) of 30 mm/hr. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient’s most likely diagnosis?

meta.key_information:
- 19-year-old woman with worsening neck pain for 5 days  
- Unable to wear tie due to neck pain  
- Associated symptoms: anxiety, palpitations, lethargy for 10 days  
- Recent flu-like illness 20 days ago  
- Physical exam: warm, sweaty extremities; severe bilateral thyroid tenderness and mild swelling; no nodules  
- Vital signs: pulse 118/min, BP 110/80 mm Hg  
- Labs: low TSH, elevated T4 and T3, ESR 30 mm/hr  
- ECG normal
meta.gold_context: Severe bilateral tenderness to palpation of her thyroid gland
meta.reason: The severe bilateral thyroid tenderness is a hallmark clinical feature that points toward subacute thyroiditis (de Quervain’s thyroiditis), which is typically post-viral and presents with painful thyroid swelling and elevated inflammatory markers (ESR). This key finding differentiates it from other causes of thyrotoxicosis such as Graves’ disease or toxic nodular goiter, which usually do not cause thyroid tenderness. Without this information, it becomes much harder to identify the correct diagnosis and thus the appropriate treatment (aspirin for inflammation and pain).

question: A previously healthy 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 15 minutes after he had a seizure. He had a fever and sore throat one week ago which improved after treatment with acetaminophen. He appears lethargic and cannot recall what happened during the episode. His vital signs are within normal limits. He is oriented to time, place, and person. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. There is muscular pain at attempts to elicit deep tendon reflexes. The patient's father died of metastatic colon cancer at the age of 57 years. He is 163 cm (5 ft 4 in) tall and weighs 55 kg (121 lb); BMI is 20.8 kg/m2. He appears chronically ill. His temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mm Hg. The conjunctiva appear pale. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft and nontender. There is a well-healed scar on the upper abdomen. His hemoglobin concentration is 10.5 g/dL and his mean corpuscular volume is 101 μm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.A: Stool antigen test for H. pylori
choices.C: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.
choices.D: Treatment with PPI, clarithromycin, and amoxicillin

original_question: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of a 1-week history of recurring black stools. An upper endoscopy shows a large nodular mass on the anterior wall of the lesser curvature of the gastric stump. meta.gold_context: Upper endoscopy shows a large nodular mass on the anterior wall of the lesser curvature of the gastric stump with biopsy samples showing polypoid, glandular formation of irregular-shaped and fused gastric cells with intraluminal mucus, demonstrating an infiltrative growth.
meta.reason: This piece of information is critical because it confirms the presence of a suspicious gastric mass with histological features suggestive of malignancy in the gastric stump, which directly influences the next step in management. Without this, the question becomes much less specific and more difficult to answer correctly, as the clinical picture alone (black stools, anemia, history of gastrectomy) could suggest multiple differential diagnoses. The biopsy result indicating an infiltrative growth is the key factor that justifies the need for further imaging (abdominopelvic CT scan) to stage the disease and plan treatment.

question: A 40-year-old man presents with a rash, oral lesions, and vision problems for 5 days. He says the rash started as a burning feeling on his face and the upper part of his torso, but soon red spots appeared in that same distribution. He says the painful oral lesions appeared about the same time as the rash. For the past 3 days, he also says he has been having double vision and dry, itchy eyes. He reports that he had a mild upper respiratory infection for a few days that preceded his current symptoms. The patient denies any chills, hematuria, abdominal or chest pain, or similar symptoms in the past. Past medical history is significant for a severe urinary tract infection diagnosed 3 weeks ago for which he has been taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole. The vital signs include: temperature 38.3℃ (101.0℉), blood pressure 110/60 mm Hg, respiratory rate 20/min, and pulse 108/min. There is a prominent conjunctival injection present. Ophthalmic examination reveals mild bilateral corneal abrasions without any evidence of frank ulceration. Laboratory findings are significant for the following: White blood cell (WBC) count 8,500/mm3 Red blood cell (RBC) count 4.20 x 106/mm3 Hematocrit 41.5% Hemoglobin 14.0 g/dL Platelet count 215,000/mm3 C-reactive protein (CRP) 86 mg/L Urine and blood cultures are pending. question: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of sudden onset of abdominal pain beginning an hour ago. There is no personal history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness and scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. There is no personal history of serious illness. His immunizations are up-to-date. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows diffuse abdominal tenderness and scleral icterus. The spleen is palpated 1–2 cm below the left costal margin. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 10 g/dL Mean corpuscular volume 90 μm3 Reticulocyte count 3% Serum Bilirubin Total 3 mg/dL Direct 0.5 mg/dL Haptoglobin 20 mg/dL (N=41–165 mg/dL) Lactate dehydrogenase 160 U/L Urine Blood 3+ Protein 1+ RBC 2–3/hpf WBC 2–3/hpf Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?"

meta.gold_context: Recent treatment with trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for UTI
meta.reason: The recent use of trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole is critical because it is a known oxidative stressor that can trigger hemolysis in patients with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency. This piece of information directly links the clinical presentation to the underlying enzymatic deficiency, making it the key to selecting the correct answer (E). Without this context, the diagnosis would be much less clear, as the symptoms and labs could be attributed to other causes of hemolysis or anemia.

question: A 72-year-old man presents to his primary care provider to discuss the frequency with which he wakes up at night to urinate. question: The success of a new treatment designed to deter people from smoking was evaluated by a team of researchers. However, some participants dropped out of the study. original_question: The success of a new treatment designed to deter people from smoking was evaluated by a team of researchers. - The remaining participants were more interested in quitting smoking.

- The question asks to identify the type of bias that invalidates the conclusion.
meta.gold_context: "The heaviest and most committed smokers in the study group were less interested in quitting and subsequently dropped out of the study."
meta.reason: This piece of information is critical because it explains why the dropout occurred and why the remaining sample was biased. Without knowing that the heaviest smokers dropped out due to lack of interest in quitting, it is difficult to understand why the attrition biased the results and led to an overestimation of the treatment’s success. This dropout is the core reason for the attrition bias, making it the gold context.

question: A 74-year-old gentleman presents to his family practitioner with the complaint of an inability to open his left eye since this morning. original_question: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of left leg swelling that started after a transcontinental flight. A duplex ultrasound of the left leg shows a noncompressible popliteal vein. A drug is prescribed that inhibits the coagulation cascade. Two weeks later, laboratory studies show: Platelet count 210,000/mm3 Partial thromboplastin time 53 seconds Prothrombin time 20 seconds Thrombin time 15 seconds (control: 15 seconds) Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed?"

meta.key_information:
- 59-year-old woman with left leg swelling after a transcontinental flight  
- Duplex ultrasound shows a noncompressible popliteal vein  
- Drug prescribed inhibits the coagulation cascade  
- Two weeks later, lab results: Platelet count 210,000/mm3, PTT 53 sec, PT 20 sec, Thrombin time 15 sec (control 15 sec)
meta.gold_context: "Two weeks later, laboratory studies show: Platelet count 210,000/mm3 Partial thromboplastin time 53 seconds Prothrombin time 20 seconds Thrombin time 15 seconds (control: 15 seconds)"
meta.reason: The lab values after two weeks of treatment are critical to differentiate which anticoagulant was prescribed. The normal platelet count and specific coagulation times help exclude drugs like unfractionated heparin (which typically prolongs thrombin time and may cause thrombocytopenia) and low molecular weight heparin, and point toward a direct oral anticoagulant like apixaban. Without these lab results, it would be difficult to identify the exact drug prescribed, making the question significantly harder.

question: A 46-year-old man presents to the clinic with a 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and coughing up blood. On questioning, he notes that he has also experienced some weight loss over the past 4 months and a change in the color of his urine, with intermittent passage of dark-colored urine during that time. The man does not have a prior history of cough or hemoptysis and has not been in contact with anyone with a chronic cough. The cough was originally productive of rust-colored sputum, but it has now progressed to the coughing up of blood and sputum at least twice daily. Sputum production is approximately 2 spoonfuls per coughing episode. Vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), respiratory rate 42/min, and pulse 88/min. Physical examination reveals an anxious but tired-looking man with mild respiratory distress and mild pallor. Laboratory and antibody tests are ordered and the findings include the following: Laboratory test Hematocrit 34% Hepatitis antibody test negative Hepatitis C antibody test negative 24-hour urinary protein 2 g Urine microscopy more than 5 RBC under high power microscopy Serum urea 140 mg/dL Serum creatinine 2.8 mg/dL Renal biopsy shows glomerulonephritis with crescent formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

choices.E: I am unable to answer this question for certain reasons.

The man does not have a prior history of cough or hemoptysis and has not been in contact with anyone with a chronic cough. The cough was originally productive of rust-colored sputum, but it has now progressed to the coughing up of blood and sputum at least twice daily. Sputum production is approximately 2 spoonfuls per coughing episode. Vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), respiratory rate 42/min, and pulse 88/min. Physical examination reveals an anxious but tired-looking man with mild respiratory distress and mild pallor. Laboratory and antibody tests are ordered and the findings include the following: Laboratory test Hematocrit 34% Hepatitis antibody test negative Hepatitis C antibody test negative 24-hour urinary protein 2 g Urine microscopy more than 5 RBC under high power microscopy Antibody test C-ANCA negative Anti MPO/P-ANCA positive Serum urea 140 mg/dL Serum creatinine 2.8 mg/dL Renal biopsy shows glomerulonephritis with crescent formation. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

meta.key_information:
- 46-year-old man with 2-week history of fever, fatigue, and hemoptysis  
- Weight loss over 4 months and intermittent dark-colored urine  
- Physical exam: mild respiratory distress, mild pallor, vital signs including respiratory rate 42/min  
- Laboratory findings: Hematocrit 34%, 24-hour urinary protein 2 g, urine microscopy >5 RBCs/HPF  
- Antibody tests: C-ANCA negative, Anti MPO/P-ANCA positive

meta.gold_context: Antibody test C-ANCA negative, Anti MPO/P-ANCA positive
meta.reason: The antibody test results are critical for differentiating between types of vasculitis. The presence of anti-MPO/P-ANCA positivity with C-ANCA negativity strongly points toward microscopic polyangiitis (MPA) rather than granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which is typically C-ANCA positive. Without this serological information, it would be very difficult to distinguish MPA from other vasculitides or infectious causes, making the question significantly more challenging.

Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

original_question: A 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation comes to the obstetrician for a prenatal visit. She has had a tingling pain in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger of her right hand for the past 6 weeks. Physical examination shows decreased sensation to pinprick touch on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger of the right hand. The pain is reproduced when the dorsal side of each hand is pressed against each other. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

meta.key_information:
- 31-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0, at 28 weeks' gestation  
- Tingling pain in the thumb, index finger, and middle finger of the right hand for 6 weeks  
- Decreased sensation to pinprick on the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and lateral half of the ring finger of the right hand  
- Pain reproduced when the dorsal sides of each hand are pressed together (Phalen's test)  
- Question asks for the most likely additional finding
meta.gold_context: Pain is reproduced when the dorsal side of each hand is pressed against each other.
meta.reason: This detail describes a positive Phalen's test, which is a key diagnostic maneuver for carpal tunnel syndrome. Without this, it is difficult to confidently link the sensory symptoms to median nerve compression at the wrist and thus predict the associated finding (thenar atrophy). The other information points to median nerve distribution but does not confirm the diagnosis as clearly as the positive Phalen's test.

question: A 58-year-old woman with breast cancer presents to her primary care physician for referral to a medical oncologist. She denies any personal history of blood clots in her past. Her past medical history is significant for preeclampsia, hypertension, polycystic ovarian syndrome, and hypercholesterolemia. She currently smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day, drinks a glass of wine per day, and she currently denies any illicit drug use, despite a history of cocaine use. The vital signs include: temperature 36.7°C (98.0°F), blood pressure 126/74 mm Hg, heart rate 111/min and irregular, and respiratory rate 17/min. On physical examination, she has a grade 2/6 holosystolic murmur heard best at the left upper sternal border, bilateral bibasilar crackles on the lungs, and a normal abdominal examination. At her follow-up with the oncologist, they plan to start the patient on chemotherapy. Which of the following regimens for the treatment of chemotherapy-induced emesis is most appropriate for patients on the same day of treatment?

meta.gold_context: Burning and tingling pain in his legs when he walks that goes away when he sits down and takes a break.
meta.reason: This symptom description is classic for intermittent claudication, which strongly suggests peripheral arterial disease (PAD). Without this key symptom, the clinical picture becomes less clear, making it difficult to identify the correct diagnostic step.

question: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of yellowish discoloration of his eyes and skin, abdominal discomfort, and generalized fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He has had dark urine and pale stools during this period. He has had a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss since his last visit 6 months ago. He has hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 34 years. He drinks three to four beers over the weekends. His only medication is amlodipine. His temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 89/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 114/74 mm Hg. Examination shows jaundice of the sclera and skin and excoriation marks on his trunk and extremities. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft and nontender. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show: Hemoglobin 12 g/dL Leukocyte count 5,000/mm3 Platelet count 400,000/mm3 Serum Urea nitrogen 28 mg/dL Creatinine 1.2 mg/dL Bilirubin Total 7.0 mg/dL Direct 5.5 mg/dL Alkaline phosphatase 615 U/L Aspartate aminotransferase (AST, GOT) 170 U/L Alanine aminotransferase (ALT, GPT) 310 U/L γ-Glutamyltransferase (GGT) 592 U/L (N = 5–50 U/L) An ultrasound shows extrahepatic biliary dilation. The patient undergoes biliary stenting. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
